awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.  The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Biz Turnell is "Female mediation of sperm metabolism in storage: an investigation across time, species, and storage organs." The host institution for this fellowship is the Dresden University of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Klaus Reinhardt.  

The goal of this research is to understand the functional consequences of sperm senescence, or aging during storage. Sperm age has long been appreciated by human fertility researchers and livestock breeders as an important factor in sperm functionality, but has largely been ignored by evolutionary biologists studying natural selection. Nonetheless, the age distribution of stored sperm is likely to account for a substantial portion of variation in reproductive success of males and to play a significant role in sperm competition and cryptic female choice since sperm can be damaged during the aging period. Previous research has shown that some female insects delay the senescence of stored sperm by reducing the sperm cells' metabolic rates, thereby limiting the cells' production of damaging reactive oxygen species. Using the cutting-edge method of time-resolved microfluorimetry, the Fellow is determining whether this mechanism underlies the spatial and temporal patterns of sperm storage and use exhibited by fruit flies (Drosophila), an excellent invertebrate model species. Drosophila females have two types of storage organ, the seminal receptacle and the spermathecae. In Drosophila melanogaster, the former is used in short-term storage while the latter are used in long-term storage. In contrast, in the closely related Drosophila simulans, the seminal receptacle favors the sperm of the first male to mate with a female while the spermathecae favor the sperm of the second male. Although decades of research have produced a detailed account of these patterns, little is known about the biochemical processes underlying them. By studying these processes at the cellular level, the Fellow will be the first to link storage and use patterns with the genomics and transcriptomics of sperm storage.  

The Fellow is being trained in the acquisition of new empirical skills, broadening intellectual and theoretical perspectives, formulating collaborations with European scientists, and developing mentoring and outreach skills. This Fellow will serve as a role model for groups underrepresented in biology, and will promote broader participation in biology by encouraging young and LGBT students as research assistants, presenting to local youth groups, and by organizing an interactive workshop.

por.por_cntn:
Like all living things, sperm cells are constantly getting older. As cells age, they accumulate damage called oxidative stress, caused by molecules known as reactive oxygen species. These molecules, a byproduct of normal metabolism, can be neutralized by antioxidants, but excess amounts can harm the cell membrane, DNA, and other parts of the cell. In sperm, this oxidative damage leads to decreased fertilizing ability and to lower offspring health. Sperm are subject to reactive oxygen species and to antioxidants from several potential sources: those produced by the sperm itself, and those produced by the male and female organs through which the sperm travels. 

Sperm aging is especially a problem for species where the female stores sperm for some period of time after mating. This time period can range from a few days in humans to up to several decades in some ants! During that time, sperm cells are constantly accumulating oxidative damage. What are the evolutionary consequences of sperm cell ageing? In the research funded by this grant, we tested the following hypotheses: (1) sperm aging via oxidative stress decreases male and female fitness; and therefore, (2) sperm aging acts as a selective pressure driving the evolution of male and female traits. 

To test hypothesis (1), we measured male and female offspring production in two types of genetically modified Drosophila fruit flies. In one type of fly, sperm ages more slowly because fewer reactive oxygen species are produced during metabolism. In the other type, sperm ages more quickly because fewer antioxidants are produced. We found that females receiving slowly aging sperm had more offspring than those receiving normal sperm and were fertile for a longer period of time, while females receiving quickly aging sperm had fewer offspring and a shorter fertility period. These results show that male and female reproductive fitness in normal flies is limited by their ability to minimize the production of reactive oxygen species and maximize the production of antioxidants. In addition, females in the fly line with quickly aging sperm mated more often than normal females. These females may have evolved such behavior in order to regularly replace their aging sperm stores with younger, undamaged sperm.  

This latter possibility leads us to experiment (2), where we tested the hypothesis that sperm aging drives the evolution of female mating rate. For reasons not fully understood, female mating rate ranges widely across Drosophila species, from once in a lifetime to several times per day. We adapted a cutting-edge method, fluorescent lifetime imaging microscopy, from the fields of cancer and stem cell research to measure sperm metabolic rates in over a dozen Drosophila species (see Figure 1 for example images). Comparing these measures to previously published data on mating behavior, we found that females mated more often in species with sperm that metabolizes, and is therefore likely to accumulate age-related damage, more quickly. Like the genetically modified females in the previous experiment, species with rapidly aging sperm may have been selected by evolution to replace their sperm stores more often in order to avoid using aged sperm to fertilize their eggs. 

In a third experiment, we examined the link between metabolic rate and oxidative stress, not in young vs. old sperm, but rather in sperm from young vs. old males. We found that older males? sperm metabolized more quickly and accumulated more reactive oxygen species, even though these sperm actually produced reactive oxygen species at a lower rate. This pattern may be explained by reduced antioxidant production in older males. We found a different pattern in gut tissue, where oxidative stress also increased with age but metabolic rate decreased. These findings suggest that the pathways of aging are different in sperm than in the rest of the body, which may have implications for male infertility treatments.

Overall, our results show that sperm metabolic rate can play as important an evolutionary role as more commonly studied sperm traits like shape and movement. Within species, sperm aging via cellular metabolism may explain why paternity success varies so much, independent of any male characteristics. Across species, sperm metabolic rate may be the key to understanding the relationships between other sperm traits, for example why sperm length and speed are positively correlated in some animals and negatively correlated in others. Finally, our study demonstrates that fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy can be used to analyze sperm metabolism, holding promise for both evolutionary and medical research.
